race.name: JEROBOAM
race.tagline: The world's toughest gravel ride where wine bottle sizes determine your suffering quota and 7,000 meters of climbing is just the appetizer.

logistics.explanation: Milan-area airports provide access to Erbusco, Lombardy with free camping at the event village. Paul Errington describes firing up the route at the airport: "12,000m of climbing! I messaged Uggi from AltomCykling.dk to ask about this crazy number." Wine country accommodation runs $100-600/night, making this a multi-day commitment in Italy's premier sparkling wine region.

length.explanation: The 300km flagship distance earned its brutal reputation through rider experience. Elite rider Paul Errington needed 21 hours to finish, noting "it was obvious that Jeroboam 300 was a serious undertaking." Dave Arthur's 150km took "9 hours (8 hrs 15 mins ride time; I had to stop for photos and snacks)." The new 600km Mathusalem pushes into true ultra territory. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Paul Errington describes "long tarmac climbs, rough descents, singletrack and gravel" where "no one rider or bike would have a distinct advantage." At 80km riders "descended back down on a rocky cart track where a mountain bike would have been at home." Jack Luke encountered "off-camber singletrack" described as "low risk, high consequence" that ended his partner's attempt. Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands.

elevation.explanation: A savage 7,000m+ (23,000ft) of climbing on the 300km, with 1,200m gained in just the first 30km. The Dolomites edition pushes to 10,000m. The Mathusalem 600km features 14,500m. This is alpine warfare. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands. As Jack Luke puts it: "As an aside, the route was also advertised as having approximately 5,000m of climbing, but in the end even our curtailed 275km route topped out with a rather heady 6,300m of ascent."

climate.explanation: Northern Italian autumn brings variable conditions - fog, mist, thunderstorms, and rain are common. Cold wet night riding is virtually guaranteed. Weather has repeatedly 'added an unpredictable layer' to the suffering. Milder conditions than Crusher in the Tushar. As Paul Errington puts it: "With a 16:00 start the day of the event was far more relaxed than normal. Lazy breakfast, last minute bike tweaks and then some pasta for lunch."

altitude.explanation: Routes traverse the Lombard Prealps with alpine road climbs. While not at extreme altitude, the continuous climbing through 3,000-6,000ft terrain affects performance over 20+ hours. Similar altitude considerations to Grinduro.

adventure.explanation: Absolute bucket list material. Mandatory night riding through alpine passes, watching sunrise after 20+ hours of suffering, circumnavigating Lake Iseo, passing through legendary Franciacorta vineyards. The wine bottle naming, 3T heritage, and 'world's toughest gravel' reputation create an unforgettable experience.

prestige.explanation: Legendary status in the ultra-gravel community as 'the world's toughest gravel ride.' Backed by 3T's Gerard Vroomen and embodying the brand's gravel philosophy. However, no UCI or major series affiliation limits global recognition outside dedicated ultra circles.

race_quality.explanation: Professional organization includes aid stations where riders find "some pasta and a hot chocolate" at mountain refuges. The event provides "aid stations along the way for food, drinks and technical support, but you should be self-sufficient." GPS tracking on 300km distances and structured checkpoints support the 24-hour format, though route conflicts occasionally arise.

experience.explanation: Life-changing for those who finish. The combination of night riding, sunrise over Italian alps, wine culture integration, suffering alongside international riders, and the sheer accomplishment of completing 300km with 7,000m climbing creates memories that last a lifetime. 'An experience I'll never forget' is a common refrain. As Jack Luke puts it: "At first glance, the Jeroboam 300, a new gravel race in the north of Italy, looked like the ideal weekend adventure — boasting copious amounts of wine, sun, good views and a largely off-road 300km loo..."

community.explanation: Strong emphasis on 'riding together' rather than racing. Organisers actively stress the community over competition ethos. Everyone described as 'super friendly and positive' despite grueling conditions. The 3T gravel philosophy attracts like-minded suffering enthusiasts. As Jack Luke puts it: "Despite the stress of getting two people and a bike to Italy, organising accommodation and kit for an overnight race, putting up with my considerably slower pace and dealing with a fair bit of grumpin..."

field_depth.explanation: Competitive but primarily European-focused. No major series or UCI points attracts serious ultra-endurance specialists rather than marquee pro names. Japan events sold out with 50 riders - this is quality over quantity. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three. As Paul Errington puts it: "With a 16:00 start the day of the event was far more relaxed than normal. Lazy breakfast, last minute bike tweaks and then some pasta for lunch."

value.explanation: EUR 100-110 entry fees provide access to "aid stations along the way for food, drinks and technical support" plus GPS tracking on 300km distances. The festival atmosphere includes "much more than a race, it's a celebration of all things cycling" with expo and events. Considering 20+ hours of support infrastructure and Italian wine country access, the value proposition delivers significantly.

expenses.explanation: The entry is cheap; everything else is not. International flights to Italy, 3-4 nights in wine country accommodation ($100-600/night), meals, and bike logistics easily push total trip costs to $1,500-2,500+ for North American riders. Higher total cost than Badlands.

distances.name: Mathusalem
distances.description: The ultimate ultra gravel odyssey - 600km with 14,500m climbing. New for 2025. For the most expert riders only.

distances.name: Jeroboam
distances.description: The flagship distance - 300km with 7,000m+ climbing. Starts late afternoon, mandatory night riding, 24-hour cutoff.

distances.description: Half the distance, still a proper challenge. 150km with ~3,000m climbing.

distances.name: Demi
distances.description: Family-friendly route designed for wine discovery through renowned vineyards.

organizer.name: REVERB Cycling in collaboration with 3T Cycling
organizer.heritage: Founded 2017 by 3T Bikes, co-founded by Gerard Vroomen (Cervelo co-founder)

surface_breakdown.note: Despite percentages, 'it averaged out to gravel' - the technical nature makes it feel like more

race_format.philosophy: Not a race, it's an endurance challenge
race_format.timing: Timed with results, but emphasis on completion
race_format.night_riding: Mandatory - significant portion in complete darkness
race_format.gate_closures: Aid stations based on 15 km/h average speed

weather.typical_conditions: Variable Italian autumn - fog, mist, rain possible
historical_notes: Hills covered in mist and fog

unique_characteristics: Distances named after wine bottle sizes (Jeroboam = 3 liters)
Set in Italy's premier sparkling wine region (Franciacorta)
Organized by 3T Bikes - they practice what they preach
Mandatory night riding creates unforgettable sunrise experiences
Multi-country series spanning Europe, Asia, Americas
Up to 30% gradients and hike-a-bike sections
Wine culture integral to event DNA
who_this_is_for: Those seeking 'world's toughest gravel' bragging rights
Wine lovers who also suffer on bikes
comparable_events: Unbound 200 (similar distance but easier - less climbing)

history.founding_story: First Jeroboam Bike Festival held in Franciacorta, backed by 3T Bikes

notable_years.2019: Third edition - first finisher matched last finisher time at Dirty Kanza
notable_years.2024: Four European events (Asiago, Czech Republic, Austria, Franciacorta)

history.founder: REVERB CYCLING in collaboration with 3T Cycling Srl

race.dataQuality: Comprehensive - verified against official sources and rider reports

final_verdict.one_liner: Italy's gravel masquerading as a wine tour until 7,000 meters of climbing and mandatory night riding separate the romantics from the masochists.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Show up undertrained and the Lombard Prealps will humble you by kilometer 30. The 4pm start means you're grinding technical singletrack in the dark with dead legs, so your bike handling better be dialed. This isn't a gravel race—it's a 24-hour suffer fest through vineyards that thinks it's the Giro.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want the European gravel experience without the night riding punishment, try Gravel One Fifty in the Dolomites or L'Eroica for vintage charm. SBT GRVL gives you similar distance and elevation but trades Italian romance for Colorado's reliable weather and better logistics.

course_description.character: Jeroboam masquerades as gravel but delivers two-thirds asphalt—don't be fooled, this isn't easy road riding. The Lombard Prealps serve up Roman cobbles, vineyard doubletrack, and 30% mountain bike trails that'll have you hiking sections. Wine country never tasted this bitter.

suffering_zones.label: The Vineyard Beating
suffering_zones.desc: First 1,200m of climbing packed into 30km through Franciacorta's famous vineyards. Those postcard views come with gradients that'll snap your chain if you're not careful.

suffering_zones.label: Lago d'Iseo Reckoning
suffering_zones.desc: Circumnavigating Italy's fourth largest lake sounds romantic until you hit the technical singletrack and loose rock descents. Tubeless isn't optional—it's survival.

suffering_zones.label: The 95% Rule
suffering_zones.desc: By checkpoint 3 at 161km, you've done 95% of the climbing but only 53% of the distance. The math doesn't lie—everything after this is about not falling apart in the dark.

suffering_zones.label: Lights On Reality
suffering_zones.desc: Mandatory lighting kicks in as you grind toward Lake Garda in complete darkness. Twenty hours is fast here—plan for longer and pack batteries accordingly.

course_description.signature_challenge: The 4pm start guarantees you'll ride most of this beast in complete darkness, navigating technical terrain with a headlamp while your body shuts down. It's not the 7,000m of climbing that breaks people—it's doing it blind for 14 hours straight.

videos.description: At first glance, the Jeroboam 300, a new gravel race in the north of Italy, looks like the ideal weekend adventure — wine, sun, good views and a largely off-road 300km loop that circumnavigates Lago d’Iseo in Erbusco. This is how BikeRadar's #radventurers, Reuben and Jack fared when they took to the start line.

videos.title: My FIRST EVER Gravel Race was...HARD (FULL Rasputitsa Gravel Race Story)
videos.description:
I did my first ever gravel race in Vermont at the Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race. IT WAS INSANE! MUD, RAIN, COLD, SNOW...It had it all! I had an absolute BLAST even though I thought I was going to lose my fingers.

Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race is a 40mi mud race in Bruke Vermont. There is lots of backcountry gravel roads with 2 very technical sections. Almost 2,000 people were registered for the race so it was full gas form the gun. 

Clifbar brought my coach Tony from ATP Coaching and my self out to the Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race to see what its all about. It did not disappoint! Gravel racing is so much fun as its a great mix between fools gas racing and having fun on a bike. 

Really hope you enjoy the full story of my first ever gravel race at the Rasputitsa Gravel Road Race. Race Starts at 7:15 Strava route here (https://www.strava.com/activities/2323609317)

videos.title: UN PERCORSO PER METTERSI ALLA PROVA: Jeroboam Gravel Franciacorta
videos.description:
Un percorso per mettersi alla prova: Jeroboam Gravel Franciacorta

In questo Vlog vi raccontiamo la Jeroboam Franciacorta 2022, percorso Magnum da 150km e 3200 metri di dislivello.

Partenza da Erbusco, in Lombardia. I primi km sono quasi tutti su sterrato, tra vigneti e single tracks. Passaggio a Clusane a ridosso del Lago d’Iseo e poi tra le Torbiere del Sebino. A Sarezzo inizia la lunga salita di giornata, interamente asfaltata/cementata di circa 10km, verso San Bernardo e Corna di Sonclino a 1300, il GPM del percorso Magnum. Discesa veloce su asfalto verso Sonico. Altri passaggi per Odolo, Gavardo, Serle e alle cave di Botticino. A Brescia digressione urban, con salita al Parco del Castello e discesa di nuovo in città. Rientro a Erbusco su ampie strade sterrate passando attraverso qualche piccolo paese.

Questo itinerario gravel ci è piaciuto molto perché è impegnativo ma sempre scorrevole e tecnicamente molto accessibile. I punti più tecnici sono sempre in salita (mai pericoloso in discesa) e con un buon allenamento si percorre tutto in sella senza mai dover scendere e camminare. Un vero percorso gravel, esigente ma che regala panorami unici ed alterna con il giusto ritmo passaggi wild in mezzo alla natura a passaggi urban nelle città/paesi.

Consigliamo pneumatici da 45mm. 

Qui la nostra traccia: https://www.komoot.it/tour/953861779

Abbiamo percorso questo itinerario cicloturistico con le nostre bici gravel 3T Exploro Racemax con single speed Campagnolo Ekar 38T e 9-42, cerchi 27.5 3T DiscusPlus i28 LTD, pneumatici Vittoria Mezcal 2.1” con AirLiner, borracce Jet Green di Elite da 550ml, portaoggetti Takuin di Elite e borse da bikepacking Internode 4L e Node2H di Miss Grape.

videos.title: Mit dem neuen Brompton G-Line beim Jeroboam Gravel in Kärnten
videos.description:
Das Jeroboam Gravel-Event in Kärnten besuche ich immer wieder gerne - tolle Stimmung, Top-Organisation, nette Leute und vor allem großartige Gravel-Strecken rund um Villach und Richtung Karawanen sind ein toller Mix! (auch wenn das Wetter nicht immer mitspielt - auch dieses Jahr sind wir nicht ganz trocken geblieben...).

Mit dem Gravelbike (oder Hardtail) ist der teilweise technische Parcours ein großer Spaß, die extra Herausforderung bestand dieses Jahr aber darin, das Ganze mit dem brandneuen Brompton G-Line abzufahren. Die Jungs von der Brompton Junction Vienna haben mir das gerade erst vorgestellt "Gravel-Klapprad" in die Hände gedrückt und mir maximal noch Alles Gute gewünscht. Wie es mir dabei auf kleinen Reifen ergangen ist, seht ihr in diesem Video.

Und weil ein paar Video-Teile dem Regen zum Opfer gefallen sind, hab ich noch einen zweiten Teil an das Video drangehängt, in dem ich euch alle Details zum neuen Brompton G-Line mitgebe und eine erste Einschätzung, wofür und für wen das alles gut sein könnte!

Besten Dank an dieser Stelle an das großartige Jeroboam Gravel (http://jeroboam.bike/locations/woerthersee/), die Brompton Junction Vienna und Citybiker (https://citybiker.at) für den Support!

quotes.text: About 30 seconds into the ride we got absolutely soaked and decided to take shelter at a petrol station because there were other riders all huddled together in the little doorway. We got hit with hailstones and absolutely torrential downpour.

There was the opportunity to ride through the night but we decided we weren't quite epic enough for that. We figured with the timings that we'd hit the big mountain pass maybe at midnight or one o'clock in the morning and obviously pitch black, and we wanted to actually see the views at that altitude.
